title: Authors and Citation
text: Judit Kisistok. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Kisistok J (2022). gglongi: Visualizing longitudinal data. R package version 0.0.0.9000, https://juditkisistok.github.io/gglongi/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {gglongi: Visualizing longitudinal data},   author = {Judit Kisistok},   year = {2022},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000},   url = {https://juditkisistok.github.io/gglongi/}, }

title: Visualizing longitudinal data
text: package allows build longitudinal plots. born need visualize genomic data time overlay clinical events treatment, scan dates, date progression date death; however, long data time component continuous value, can use gglongi analysis workflow.

title: Visualizing longitudinal data
text: can install development version gglongi GitHub :

title: Visualizing longitudinal data
text: basic example shows create longitudinal plot:
code: library(gglongi) data("mafs") data("treatment") data("scans") data("clinical_events")  ## basic example code ## colored rectangles represent the type and duration of treatment ## dotted, red and black lines correspond to scan, progression and death dates, respectively  gglongi(mafs, x_val = "time_from_baseline", y_val = "MAF", col_val = "Gene",          col_legend = TRUE, mean_line = TRUE, x_title = "Days from baseline sample",          y_title = "Mutant allele frequency", treatments = treatment, scans = scans,          events = clinical_events, treatment_start = "start_from_baseline",          treatment_end = "stop_from_baseline", treatment_drug = "Treatment_drug",          scan_date = "Days_from_baseline", event_date = "Days_from_baseline")

title: Time of clinical events — clinical_events
text: dataset containing type timing clinical events.

title: Time of clinical events — clinical_events
text: data frame 2 rows 2 variables: Event type event, ie. Progression Death Days_from_baseline time passed first sampling time point, days

title: Visualize longitudinal data — gglongi
text: Visualize longitudinal data

title: Visualize longitudinal data — gglongi
code: gglongi(   data,   x_val,   y_val,   col_val,   col_legend = TRUE,   mean_line = TRUE,   x_title = x_val,   y_title = y_val,   treatments = NA,   scans = NA,   events = NA,   treatment_start,   treatment_end,   treatment_drug,   scan_date,   event_date )

title: Visualize longitudinal data — gglongi
text: data data.frame containing data used visualization x_val string referring name column visualized X axis. y_val string referring name column visualized Y axis. col_val string referring name column used color points plot. col_legend boolean value. TRUE, color legend displayed. mean_line boolean value. TRUE, mean values per time point calculated added continuous line. x_title string used label X axis. y_title string used label X axis. treatments data.frame containing treatment information. 3 columns: column containing name drug column containing time information start treatment column containing time information end treatment scans data.frame containing information scan dates. contain column denoting time scan. events data.frame containing information clinical events. contain type event associated timing event. treatment_start string referring name column containing treatment start data. treatment_end string referring name column containing treatment end data. treatment_drug string referring name column containing treatment drug. scan_date string referring name column containing scan date scans data frame. event_date string referring name column containing event date events data frame.

title: Visualize longitudinal data — gglongi
text: ggplot object.

title: Visualize longitudinal data — gglongi
code: mafs <- data.frame(time_from_baseline = c(0, 0, 0, 27, 27),                    MAF = c(0, 0.009, 0.007, 0.012, 0.032),                    Gene = c('BRAF', 'BRAF', 'BRAF', 'TP53', 'TP53'))  treatment = data.frame(Treatment_drug = c('Drug 1', 'Drug 2'),                        start_from_baseline = c(0, 307),                        stop_from_baseline = c(224, 538))  scans = data.frame(Scan_num = c(1, 2, 3),                    Days_from_baseline = c(12, 247, 499))  clinical_events = data.frame(Event = c('Progression', 'Death'),                              Days_from_baseline = c(273, 620))  gglongi(mafs, x_val = "time_from_baseline", y_val = "MAF", col_val = "Gene",         col_legend = TRUE, mean_line = TRUE, x_title = "Days from baseline sample",         y_title = "Mutant allele frequency", treatments = treatment, scans = scans,         events = clinical_events, treatment_start = "start_from_baseline",         treatment_end = "stop_from_baseline", treatment_drug = "Treatment_drug",         scan_date = "Days_from_baseline", event_date = "Days_from_baseline")

what: MAFs for 21 genes and 5 time points — mafs
title: MAFs for 21 genes and 5 time points — mafs
text: dataset containing 5 longitudinal sampling time points associated MAF values 21 genes.

title: MAFs for 21 genes and 5 time points — mafs
MAFs for 21 genes and 5 time points — mafs
text: data frame 101 rows 3 variables: Gene gene symbol time_from_baseline time passed first sampling time point, days MAF mutant allele frequency

what: Calculate the mean value per time point — mean_val_per_timepoint
title: Calculate the mean value per time point — mean_val_per_timepoint
text: Calculate mean value per time point

title: Calculate the mean value per time point — mean_val_per_timepoint
Calculate the mean value per time point — mean_val_per_timepoint
text: data data.frame used calculation. contain column values summarized, corresponding time points denoting measurement taken. Zero-value entries ignored completely removed calculation, unless every value corresponding time point zero. time_col string Name column containing time data. val_col string Name column containing values summarize.

title: Calculate the mean value per time point — mean_val_per_timepoint
text: tibble containing mean value individual time point. data frame contains two columns - original time_col column calculated mean value column format Mean_[val_col].

title: Calculate the mean value per time point — mean_val_per_timepoint
code: x <- data.frame(          days_from_baseline = c(0, 0, 0, 27, 27),          MAF = c(0, 0.009, 0.007, 0.012, 0.032))  mean_val_per_timepoint(x, 'days_from_baseline', 'MAF') #> # A tibble: 2 × 2 #>   days_from_baseline Mean_MAF #>                <dbl>    <dbl> #> 1                  0    0.008 #> 2                 27    0.022

title: Pipe operator — %>%
text: See magrittr::%>% details.

title: Pipe operator — %>%
text: lhs value magrittr placeholder. rhs function call using magrittr semantics.

title: Pipe operator — %>%
text: result calling rhs(lhs).

title: Time of CT scans — scans
text: dataset containing times performed CT scans.

title: Time of CT scans — scans
text: data frame 3 rows 2 variables: Scan_num order scan Days_from_baseline time passed first sampling time point, days

title: Treatment data — treatment
text: dataset containing time frames treatment drugs used.

title: Treatment data — treatment
text: data frame 2 rows 3 variables: Treatment_drug name drug start_from_baseline treatment start first sampling time point, days stop_from_baseline treatment end first sampling time point, days
